channel.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

image.title: CNN.com - RSS Channel - App International Edition

channel.copyright: Copyright (c) 2020 Turner Broadcasting System, Inc. All Rights Reserved.

item.title: Sweden says its coronavirus approach has worked. The numbers suggest a different story
Trump returns to the stage with underwhelming testing promises
CNN fact check: The most important misleading claim came from Pence
item.description: CNN's Daniel Dale fact-checks Vice President Mike Pence's response about coronavirus tests during a White House task force briefing.

item.title: WHO issues warning. Future pandemics likely to be more frequent and deadly, leading scientists say.
China is installing surveillance cameras outside homes ... and sometimes even inside
item.description: The morning after Ian Lahiffe returned to Beijing, he found a surveillance camera being mounted on the wall outside his apartment door. Its lens was pointing right at him.

item.title: Bill Gates predicts when we'll get a coronavirus vaccine
item.description: Bill Gates, philanthropist and founder of Microsoft, discusses the timeline for a potential vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Pentagon officially releases UFO videos
item.description: The Pentagon has officially released three short videos showing "unidentified aerial phenomena" that had previously been released by a private company.

item.title: New Zealand says it has 'eliminated' the virus. Here's how the country did it
item.description: After weeks of lockdown, New Zealand has achieved its ambitious goal of eliminating the coronavirus.

item.title: Trump adds to confusion over Kim Jong Un's health status
Women account for 60% of job losses over 2 months
item.description: CNN's Kyung Lah speaks with several women about how the coronavirus pandemic has halted their small businesses.

item.title: Coronavirus could be tied to a rare but serious illness in children, doctors say
item.description: A small but rising number of children are becoming ill with a rare syndrome that could be linked to coronavirus, with reported cases showing symptoms of abdominal pain, gastrointestinal symptoms and cardiac inflammation, UK health care bosses and pediatrics specialists have warned.

item.title: Accidental disinfectant poisonings in children on the rise during pandemic
The President of El Salvador has authorized lethal force by police and military against gangs after a deadly weekend
item.description: El Salvador President Nayib Bukele has authorized the use of lethal force by the police and army against gang members he says are taking advantage of the coronavirus pandemic, after a weekend of violence left at least 50 people dead across the country.

item.title: US oil falls below $11 a barrel as supply concerns keep roiling markets
Antigen tests: the coronavirus 'breakthrough' that a top White House official says we need
item.description: Dr. Deborah Birx, the White House coronavirus response coordinator, says current technology makes it impossible to test every American for coronavirus. The United States, she says, will need a "breakthrough" in testing to screen large numbers of people.

item.title: This is what coronavirus capitalism looks like
item.description: Covid-19 continues to awkwardly expose the weird morality of American capitalism, where it's OK for companies to swarm for government help while individual families and small businesses struggle.

item.title: The largest-ever Arctic ozone hole developed this spring. Now, scientists say it's closed.
item.description: An ozone hole that formed over the Arctic this spring and eventually grew into the largest ever recorded there has closed.

item.title: Reporter explains why he doesn't walk out when Trump insults him
item.description: Brian Stelter asks: Why don't they just walk out when they're insulted? ABC White House correspondent Jonathan Karl, author of "Front Row at The Trump Show, says he gets asked that question often. "As reporters, our job is to be there," he says. "The insults don't matter. Who cares?" He says "we are there to try to get the facts and to put the questions to those who are in power in this country."

item.title: Mitch McConnell's phony gesture to 'future generations'
item.description: Last week, while making an argument that states should consider bankruptcy rather than asking the federal government for money to stave off fiscal disaster amid the global Covid-19 pandemic, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell invoked his deep and obviously sincere concern for "future generations" of American taxpayers.

item.title: Experts say states easing restrictions too early may increase the US coronavirus death toll
item.description: A leading coronavirus model has upped its predicted death toll again, this time projecting 74,000 Americans will lose their lives to the virus by August.

item.title: Trump's coronavirus response has Republicans worried about November's election
CNN's Tapper stunned by 'indecent and obscene' Trump retweet
item.description: CNN's Jake Tapper and Dana Bash are both stunned by President Trump's retweet that suggests that his rivals are inflating coronavirus death rates to hurt his re-election chances.

item.title: Contact tracing 101: How it works, who could get hired, and why it's so critical in fighting coronavirus
item.description: Thousands of Americans could soon join the ranks of disease detectives in one of the most important battles against coronavirus.

item.title: Brooke Baldwin: I thought a lot about this when I was sick
item.description: CNN's Brooke Baldwin returns to work after a weeks-long fight against novel coronavirus.

item.title: The first medical doctor to play in the NFL went from a Super Bowl win to the coronavirus front line
item.description: Laurent Duvernay-Tardif was playing in the biggest game of his life less than three months ago, bringing home the Kansas City Chiefs' first Super Bowl victory in 50 years.

item.title: Saudi Arabia stops death penalty for people who committed crimes as minors
item.description: Saudi Arabia is abolishing the death penalty for people who committed crimes as minors, the state-backed Human Rights Commission (HRC) said in a statement Sunday.

item.title: Attorney General William Barr tells prosecutors to be on watch for 'overbearing' coronavirus measures
item.description: Attorney General William Barr told federal prosecutors across the country to be on guard for overbearing state and local coronavirus measures.

item.title: Photographer says this is the most challenging footage he's ever shot
item.description: A photographer captured video of dolphins glowing as they glide through bioluminescent ocean water at night.

item.title: Number of coronavirus cases on second US navy warship hit by outbreak nears 50
item.description: Nearly 50 sailors from the USS Kidd have tested positive for coronavirus, according to the US Navy.

item.title: How Kim Jong Un came into power
item.description: Kim Jong Un, his father and grandfather have ruled North Korea since 1948, steering the country through war, famine and nuclear tests.

item.title: California governor frustrated at images of crowded beaches: 'This virus doesn't take the weekends off'
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom sent a clear message to his state's residents after images circulated of throngs of crowds on Ventura and Orange County beaches this weekend: stop flouting social distancing guidelines or it could delay the state's reopening.

item.title: Parking lot turned into morgue as UK's ethnic communities hit hard by pandemic
item.description: A son grieves alone in an underground parking lot turned morgue, a daughter sheds tears for her father -- just two stories of heartbreak from communities disproportionately affected by Covid-19 in the UK. CNN's Phil Black reports.

item.title: Tesla's latest Autopilot feature is slowing down for green lights, too
item.description: Tesla has said its latest version of Autopilot, its autonomous driving software, is able to stop at traffic lights. But some Tesla drivers are learning it doesn't just stop at red lights, it appears to slow down for green lights, too.

item.title: She's been falsely accused of starting the coronavirus. Her life has been turned upside down
item.description: Maatje Benassi, a US Army reservist and mother of two, has become the target of conspiracy theorists who falsely place her at the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, saying she brought the disease to China.

item.title: Families sue Atlanta senior-care facility at heart of deadly Covid-19 outbreak
item.description: Three families are suing a home for seniors in Atlanta after the deaths of elderly residents who tested positive for the coronavirus.

item.title: Neanderthal fathers were younger than homo sapiens, but mothers were older, study says
item.description: When human ancestors left Africa and met Neanderthals in Europe 50,000 years ago, they had children together and clues were left behind in modern human DNA.

item.title: Planting trees could help this city prevent 400 premature deaths
item.description: Many cities around the world are planting trees as a way to fight climate change.

item.title: Priyanka Chopra's bold fashion has made her a global style icon
item.description: Priyanka Chopra is an actress, producer, philanthropist, singer and former Miss World. And, as has become evident in recent seasons, she is also a style icon.

item.title: 'American Idol' contestants perform from home
item.description: "American Idol" contestants and judges continue with the singing competition from their homes. HLN's Melissa Knowles has more.

item.title: Some seniors isolated with Alzheimer's and dementia are getting robotic therapy pets
item.description: Since the coronavirus outbreak, strict visitation rules and social distancing guidelines imposed at nursing homes in Florida have left some seniors feeling isolated.

item.title: Streep, Baranski and McDonald sing in their bathrobes
item.description: Meryl Streep, Audra McDonald and Christine Baranski livestreamed themselves in their bathrobes singing "The Ladies Who Lunch."

item.title: Why two women dancing is so rare
item.description: Director Andrew Margetson portrays a relatively rare sight in the world of ballet: a female pas de deux.

item.title: Big chunks of history (and rock) are missing in North America, study says
item.description: Visitors to Pikes Peak in Colorado may not notice that anything is amiss, but ask a geologist and she'll tell you that something is missing.

item.title: Sweden says its resistance to full lockdown has worked. The numbers suggest a different story
item.description: Sweden has been an outlier during the coronavirus outbreak. The country has not joined many of its European neighbors in imposing strict limits on citizens' lives, and images of people heading to work on busy streets, or chatting at cafes and bars have raised eyebrows.

item.title: Trump takes no responsibility for any spike in people using disinfectants improperly
item.description: President Donald Trump said Monday that he takes no responsibility for any spike in people using disinfectants improperly after dangerously suggesting last week that ingesting it could serve as a coronavirus treatment.

item.title: Worldwide virus cases top 3 million
Trump returns to the stage with underwhelming testing promises
item.description: • Analysis: Trump ranted against briefings, but he ultimately just can't help himself • Fact check: Trump repeats false claims and Pence misleads on previous testing comments

item.title: Trump adds to confusion over Kim Jong Un's health status
item.description: • Rumors surrounding Kim not 'based on the facts,' says former N Korean diplomat

item.title: US oil falls below $11 a barrel
item.description: US oil prices are still plunging as investors continue to fret about an excess supply of crude at a time when no one wants any.

item.title: World's biggest car factory reopens after shutting down for longest period ever
item.description: Volkswagen reopened the world's biggest car factory at Wolfsburg in Germany on Monday after the coronavirus forced it to shut down for the longest period in its 82-year history.
